{{Infobox hospital | Name = Alvin J. Siteman
Cancer Center | Location = [[St. Louis]] | State = [[Missouri]] | Type = Specialist | Speciality = [[Cancer]] | Affiliation = [[Barnes-Jewish Hospital]], [[Washington University School of Medicine]] | Founded = 1999 | Website = http://www.siteman.wustl.edu |}} The '''Alvin J. Siteman Cancer Center''' at [[Barnes-Jewish Hospital]] and [[Washington University School of Medicine]] is a cancer treatment, research and education institution with six locations in the [[St. Louis]] area. Siteman is the only cancer center in Missouri and within 240 miles of St. Louis to be designated a [[Comprehensive Cancer Center]] by the [[National Cancer Institute]] (NCI).{{cite news | last = VandeWater | first = Judith | title = St. Louis cancer center achieves highest designation | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 4 January 2005 | url = http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-7767343_ITM | accessdate = 27 June 2012}} Siteman is also the only area member of the [[National Comprehensive Cancer Network]],{{cite web | title = NCCN Member Institutions | publisher = National Comprehensive Cancer Network | url= http://www.nccn.org/members/network.asp | accessdate = 27 March 2012 }} a nonprofit alliance of 28 cancer centers dedicated to improving the quality and effectiveness of cancer care.{{cite news | title = Siteman joins cancer center alliance | newspaper = St. Louis Business Journal | date = 21 March 2006 | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/stories/2006/03/20/daily21.html | accessdate = 29 June 2012}} In 2015, Siteman received the highest rating possible - exceptional - by the NCI for cancer research. At Siteman's review leading to the rating, researchers presented their findings in genomics, cancer imaging, cancer prevention and disparities, and the use of the body's immune system to fight cancer.{{cite news |last= Munz |first= Michele |date= 7 July 2015 |title= Siteman Cancer Center earns highest rating from federal cancer institute |url= http://www.stltoday.com/business/local/siteman-cancer-center-earns-highest-rating-from-federal-cancer-institute/article_1ddf4080-0a7e-5d7b-a5ef-49b600ccda19.html |newspaper= St. Louis Post-Dispatch |location= St. Louis, Missouri |access-date= 14 September 2015}} In 2018, Siteman was named a top 15 U.S. cancer center by [[U.S. News & World Report]].{{cite web | title = Siteman Cancer Center Rankings & Ratings | publisher= U.S. News & World Report | url= https://health.usnews.com/best-hospitals/area/mo/barnes-jewish-hospitalwashington-university-6630930/cancer?int=scorecard-specialty-click | accessdate = 14 August 2018}} The recognition is part of the overall ranking of its parent institutions, Barnes-Jewish Hospital, which is tied for No. 11 on the newsmagazine's “The Best Hospitals 2018-19 Honor Roll,”{{cite magazine | last1=Comarow | first1=Avery | last2=Harder | first2=Ben | date= 14 August 2018 | title = 2018-19 Best Hospitals Honor Roll and Medical Specialties Rankings | publisher= U.S. News & World Report | url= https://health.usnews.com/health-care/best-hospitals/articles/best-hospitals-honor-roll-and-overview | accessdate = 14 August 2018}} and Washington University School of Medicine, which is No. 8 on the newsmagazine's "2019 Best Medical Schools: Research" list.{{cite web | title = 2019 Best Medical Schools: Research | publisher= U.S. News & World Report | url= https://www.usnews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-medical-schools/research-rankings | accessdate = 14 August 2018}} In 2014, Siteman treated nearly 9,000 newly diagnosed cancer patients{{cite news | title = Siteman Cancer Center earns top federal agency rating | newspaper = St. Louis Business Journal | date = 10 July 2015 }} and every year provides continuing care to about 40,000 people, making it one of the largest cancer centers in the United States.{{cite web | title = Summary 3: Reportable Patients/Participation in Therapeutic Protocols | publisher = National Comprehensive Cancer Network | url = http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/data/sum3.html | accessdate = 6 April 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111113051358/http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/data/sum3.html | archive-date = 2011-11-13 | dead-url = yes | df = }} ==Locations== Siteman’s main facility is at [[Washington University Medical Center]] in St. Louis’ [[Central West End]] neighborhood. Five other St. Louis-area sites offer specialized cancer care in suburban locations: {{bulleted list |[[BJC HealthCare#Barnes–Jewish West County|Barnes-Jewish West County Hospital]] in [[Creve Coeur, Missouri]] |[[BJC HealthCare#Barnes–Jewish St. Peters Hospital|Barnes-Jewish St. Peters Hospital]] in [[St. Peters, Missouri]] |[[BJC HealthCare#Christian Hospital|Christian Hospital]] in north [[St. Louis County, Missouri]]{{cite news | last = Bouscaren | first = Durrie | title = Siteman Cancer Center expands to north St. Louis County | newspaper = St. Louis Public Radio | date = 30 June 2017 | url = http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/siteman-cancer-center-expands-north-st-louis-county#stream/0 | accessdate = 3 October 2017 }} |Siteman Cancer Center-South County in south St. Louis County, Missouri{{cite news | last = Liss | first = Samantha | title = $27.5 million outpatient Siteman Cancer Center to open Monday | newspaper = St. Louis Business Journal | date = 2 January 2013 | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/blog/2013/01/275-million-outpatient-siteman.html | accessdate = 11 January 2013 }} |[[Swansea, Illinois]]{{cite news |last=Maddox |first=Teri |date=7 August 2018 |title= You can now get treatment for cancer at Siteman without having to go to St. Louis |url=https://www.bnd.com/news/local/article216173550.html |work=Belleville News-Democrat |accessdate=14 August 2018}}}} ==History and leadership== In 1999, Alvin J. and Ruth Siteman committed $35 million to the development of the Siteman Cancer Center at Washington University School of Medicine and Barnes-Jewish Hospital. The commitment was the largest gift ever received by Barnes-Jewish and Washington University in support of cancer research, patient care and services, education and community outreach.{{cite news | title = Couple donate $35 million for cancer research | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 20 November 1999 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=%20COUPLE%20DONATE%20$%2035%20MILLION%20FOR%20CANCER%20RESEARCH | accessdate = 24 June 2013}}{{subscription needed}} Timothy Eberlein, M.D., has been director of the center since its inception.{{cite news | title = Siteman Cancer Center gets $23M | newspaper = St. Louis Business Journal | date = 1 November 2010 | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2010/11/01/wash-u-gets-23m-for-siteman-cancer.html | accessdate = 27 March 2012}} John DiPersio, M.D., Ph.D., is deputy director.{{cite web | title = National Comprehensive Cancer Network, MD, PhD | publisher= Siteman Cancer Center | url= http://www.siteman.wustl.edu/DocProfile.aspx?Type=Patient&memid=85 | accessdate = 29 March 2012 }} In 2001, the NCI designated Siteman as a Cancer Center, which signaled that the institution had demonstrated significant scope and quality in its cancer research programs. The designation came with $850,000 per year in federal research grants.{{cite news | last = VandeWater | first = Judith | title = Siteman Center Here Wins Designation from National Cancer Institute | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 16 August 2001 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=SITEMAN%20CENTER%20HERE%20WINS%20DESIGNATION%20FROM%20NATIONAL%20CANCER%20INSTITUTE&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=2001&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=%28%22SITEMAN%20CENTER%20HERE%20WINS%20DESIGNATION%20FROM%20NATIONAL%20CANCER%20INSTITUTE%22%29&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no | accessdate = 15 June 2012}} The NCI named Siteman a Comprehensive Cancer Center in 2005, recognizing its broad-based research, outreach and education activities, and awarded the center a five-year, $21 million support grant.{{cite news | last = VandeWater | first = Judith | title = Siteman Cancer Center here achieves highest designation | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 4 January 2005 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Siteman%20Cancer%20Center%20here%20achieves%20highest%20designation&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=2005&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=%28%22Siteman%20Cancer%20Center%20here%20achieves%20highest%20designation%22%29&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no | accessdate = 15 June 2012}} The NCI renewed the designation in 2010 and awarded another five-year grant, totaling $23 million. The grants fund programs and specialized services that promote multidisciplinary research, as well as shared scientific resources and seed awards that enable investigators to develop and pursue new research opportunities.{{cite news | last = Munz | first = Michele | title = Siteman Cancer Center designated as Comprehensive Cancer Center, gets $23 million | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 21 November 2010 | url = http://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/health-med-fit/health/health-matters/siteman-cancer-center-designated-as-comprehensive-cancer-center-gets-million/article_30960ad2-f5b2-11df-b89e-00127992bc8b.html | accessdate = 13 April 2012}} Alvin J. Siteman announced in 2010 that he would donate $1 million annually to an endowment fund at the center to advance cancer prevention, diagnosis and treatment programs that might not receive federal funding.{{cite news | title = St. Louis philanthropist endows cancer fund | newspaper = The Associated Press | date = 26 January 2010 | url = http://www.kmov.com/news/local/82667972.html | accessdate = 15 June 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100407040135/http://www.kmov.com/news/local/82667972.html | archive-date = 2010-04-07 | dead-url = yes | df = }} ==Patient care and services== More than 350 Washington University research scientists and physicians provide inpatient and outpatient care at Siteman.{{cite web | title= NCCN Member Institution Profile | publisher= National Comprehensive Cancer Network | url= http://www.nccn.com/component/content/article/42/209-siteman-cancer-center.html | accessdate= 15 March 2012 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120512053015/http://nccn.com/component/content/article/42/209-siteman-cancer-center.html | archive-date= 2012-05-12 | dead-url= yes | df= }} The center also offers patient and family support services, including discussion and education groups.{{cite web | title = Patient & Visitor Information | publisher= Siteman Cancer Center | url= http://www.siteman.wustl.edu/SectionFront.aspx?id=3738&mid=9 | accessdate = 15 May 2012}} ==Research== Scientists and physicians affiliated with Siteman hold more than $145 million in cancer research and related training grants. The results of basic laboratory research are rapidly incorporated into treatment advances. This process is enhanced by patient access to more than 500 therapeutic clinical studies,{{cite web | title = Find A Clinical Trial | publisher= Siteman Cancer Center | url= http://www.siteman.wustl.edu/FindProtocol.aspx | accessdate = 15 October 2017}} including many collaborative efforts with other leading cancer centers throughout the country.{{cite web | title = About Siteman | publisher= Siteman Cancer Center | url= https://siteman.wustl.edu/about/about-siteman/ | accessdate = 27 October 2017}} In 2013, three scientists affiliated with Siteman, Washington University School of Medicine and the [[McDonnell Genome Institute]] were included on the [[Thomson Reuters]] list of “Hottest Scientific Researchers of 2012”: [[Richard K. Wilson]], Ph.D.; [[Elaine Mardis]], Ph.D.; and Li Ding, Ph.D. The list recognized the 21 most-cited researchers of 2012. Robert Fulton, a fourth scientist from Washington University School of Medicine and the [[McDonnell Genome Institute]], also made the list.{{cite web | title = Who and What Was Hot in Scientific Research in 2012 | url = http://sciencewatch.com/articles/hottest-research-2012 | accessdate = 5 June 2013}} ===Research advances=== Researchers affiliated with Siteman and/or Washington University School of Medicine have pioneered important advances in cancer research, prevention, education and treatment. Highlights and ongoing studies include these projects: '''2018 — Personalized brain cancer vaccines''' * In a clinical trial to test the effectiveness of a [[glioblastoma]] vaccine, some patients "lived significantly longer" - up to seven years longer - than most people who are diagnosed with the brain cancer. Researchers developed personalized vaccines for each patient, removing as much of the brain tumor as possible, then combining pieces of the tumor with cells from the patient’s immune system. This “trains” the immune cells to attack tumor cells.{{cite news |last=Berson |first=Scott |date=30 May 2018 |title=Scientists created a brain-cancer vaccine - and so far it's 'remarkably promising' |url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article212173189.html |work=The McClatchy Company/Miami Herald |accessdate=14 August 2018}} '''2017 — CAR-T cell therapy and using Zika virus to fight brain cancer''' * In a clinical trial at Siteman, at least 16 of 20 people who received a new treatment called CAR-T cell therapy saw their cancers disappear after treatment. The patients had previously failed standard therapies.{{cite news |last= Bernhard |first= Blythe |date= 19 August 2017 |title= New treatment for deadly blood cancers expected to be approved soon |url= http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/new-treatment-for-deadly-blood-cancers-expected-to-be-approved/article_14a09d12-5eea-5c3f-94bd-2a216e1eb58f.html |newspaper= St. Louis Post-Dispatch |access-date= 3 October 2017}} The therapy, [[Axicabtagene ciloleucel]], received FDA approval on Oct. 18, 2017.{{cite news |last= McGinley |first= Laurie |date= 18 October 2017 |title= Cutting-edge immunotherapy treatment approved for another deadly cancer |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2017/10/19/cutting-edge-immunotherapy-treatment-approved-for-yet-another-deadly-cancer |newspaper= The Washington Post |access-date= 25 October 2017}} * While Zika virus causes devastating damage to the brains of developing fetuses, it one day may be an effective treatment for glioblastoma, a deadly form of brain cancer. Joint research from Washington University School of Medicine and [[UC San Diego School of Medicine]] shows that the virus kills brain cancer stem cells, the kind of cells most resistant to standard treatments.{{cite news |last= Roberts |first= Michelle |date= 5 September 2017 |title= Zika virus used to treat aggressive brain cancer |url= http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/new-treatment-for-deadly-blood-cancers-expected-to-be-approved/article_14a09d12-5eea-5c3f-94bd-2a216e1eb58f.html |newspaper= St. Louis Post-Dispatch |access-date= 3 October 2017}} '''2016 — Chemotherapy for brain tumors''' * Neurosurgeons using lasers to treat brain cancer discover that the technique breaks down the blood-brain barrier for about four weeks, allowing them to use chemotherapy to treat the tumor. A clinical trial is still ongoing, but Eric C. Leuthardt, M.D., considers the initial results promising.{{cite news |last= Gruber |first= Ben |date= 4 May 2016 |title= Laser brain cancer treatment may bring extra advantage |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-cancer-brain-idUSKCN0XV28A |newspaper= Reuters |access-date= 13 May 2016}} '''2015 — Melanoma vaccine and urine test for kidney cancer''' * In a proof of concept study, a research team led by Beatriz Carreno, Ph.D., shows that personalized medicine can "wake up" the immune systems of melanoma patients. Further study needs to be done to see if the customized vaccines can prevent recurrence in patients with advanced melanoma.{{cite news |last= Norton |first= Amy |date= 2 April 2015 |title= Experimental Melanoma Vaccine Shows Early Promise |url= http://consumer.healthday.com/cancer-information-5/mis-cancer-news-102/experimental-melanoma-vaccine-shows-early-promise-698026.html |newspaper= HealthDay |access-date= 14 September 2015}} * A urine-based screening test is found to be more than 95 percent accurate in identifying early-stage kidney cancer, according to a study led by Evan Kharasch, M.D., Ph.D.{{cite news |date= 20 March 2015 |title= Urine Test Shows Promise for Early Diagnosis of Kidney Cancer |url= http://consumer.healthday.com/cancer-information-5/kidney-cancer-news-431/urine-test-shows-promise-for-early-diagnosis-of-kidney-cancer-697607.html |newspaper= HealthDay |access-date= 14 September 2015}} '''2014 — Breast cancer vaccine and cancer goggles''' * A breast cancer vaccine developed by William Gillanders, M.D., is shown to activate the immune system to fight tumor cells and slow down cancer progression. The vaccine, which targets [[mammaglobin-A]], a protein expressed in breast tumors, involved very few side effects.{{cite news |last= Mahesh |first= Roshni |date= 2 December 2014 |title= Vaccine to Slow Down Metastatic Breast Cancer |url= http://www.ibtimes.co.in/vaccine-slow-down-metastatic-breast-cancer-615771 |newspaper= International Business Times |access-date= 14 September 2015}} * High-tech goggles developed by [[Samuel Achilefu]], Ph.D., help surgeons see cancer cells in real time. The technology, which includes a digital display, infrared light and use of an intravenous dye, could negate the need for follow-up surgeries due to undetected cancer cells.{{cite news |last= Mintz |first= Joe |date= 11 February 2014 |title= New Glasses Makes Sure ‘No Cancer Is Left Behind,’ Causes Malignant Cells To Glow Blue |url= http://www.ibtimes.com/new-glasses-makes-sure-no-cancer-left-behind-causes-malignant-cells-glow-blue-photo-1554755 |newspaper= International Business Times |access-date= 14 September 2015}} '''2013 — Endometrial cancer and leukemia''' * In separate studies, researchers at Washington University School of Medicine and the [[McDonnell Genome Institute]] help identify major genetic mutations that promote [[endometrial cancer]] and [[acute myeloid leukemia]]. The research, part of [[The Cancer Genome Atlas]] project, provides new information that could change treatments for patients and aid drug development.{{cite news | last = Winslow | first = Ron | title = Genomic Studies Unlock Details on Two Cancers | newspaper = The Wall Street Journal | date = 1 May 2013 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324582004578456701717954658 | accessdate = 1 May 2013}} '''2012 — Leukemia, breast cancer research and cancer prevention''' * Siteman leukemia doctor Lukas Wartman, M.D., who was diagnosed with the disease himself, goes into remission for an unprecedented third time after [[Timothy Ley]], M.D., and his colleagues at the [[McDonnell Genome Institute]] sequenced Wartman’s cancerous and normal genes. Researchers also analyzed his [[RNA]]. By doing so, his treatment team, which includes John DiPersio, M.D., Ph.D., deputy director of Siteman, discovered that a normal gene might be contributing to the growth of Wartman's cancer by producing mass amounts of a certain protein. They found that a drug used to treat a type of kidney cancer was able to inhibit the gene.{{cite news | last = Kolata | first = Gina | title = In Treatment for Leukemia, Glimpses of the Future | newspaper = The New York Times | date = 7 July 2012 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/08/health/in-gene-sequencing-treatment-for-leukemia-glimpses-of-the-future.html?pagewanted=all | accessdate = 20 July 2012 }}{{cite episode | title = Frontiers in Cancer Research | episodelink = | url = http://www.charlierose.com/view/interview/12455 | series = Charlie Rose | serieslink = | network = PBS | location = New York | airdate = 17 July 2012 | minutes = 28 | access-date = 2012-07-20 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120721201331/http://www.charlierose.com/view/interview/12455 | archivedate = 2012-07-21 | deadurl = yes | df = }} * Scientists including Matthew Ellis, M.B., Ph.D., use [[whole genome sequencing]] to compare differences between the [[DNA]] of breast cancer tumors and healthy cells in 46 women. While revealing the complexity of the disease, the analysis suggests routes to personalized medicine that may have a greater probability of healing patients.{{cite news | title = Gene therapy: Genetic mutations predict which cancers will respond to treatment | newspaper = The Economist | date = 16 June 2012 | url = http://www.economist.com/node/21556896 | accessdate = 16 June 2012}} * Building on his research for the [[Nurses Health Study]] and [[Growing Up Today Study]],{{cite news | title = In Nurses’ Lives, a Treasure Trove of Health Data | newspaper = The New York Times | date = 15 September 1998 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/science/in-nurses-lives-a-treasure-trove-of-health-data.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm | accessdate = 29 June 2012}} [[Graham Colditz]], M.D., Dr.P.H., continues to examine links between cancer and alcohol use,{{cite news | last = Dohney | first = Kathleen | title = Teen Drinking May Boost Odds of Precancerous Breast Changes | publisher = HealthDay News and U.S. News & World Report | date = 9 April 2011 | url = http://health.usnews.com/health-news/news/articles/2012/04/09/teen-drinking-may-boost-odds-of-precancerous--breast-changes | accessdate = 16 April 2012}} diet, exercise and other factors{{cite news | last = Harmon | first = Katherine | title = U.S. Cancer Rates Could Be Cut in Half Today Based on What’s Already Known | publisher = Scientific American | date = 28 March 2011 | url = http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/2012/03/28/u-s-cancer-rates-could-be-cut-in-half-today-based-on-whats-already-known/?WT.mc_id=SA_syn_HuffPo | accessdate = 16 April 2012}} and what individuals and communities can do to reduce disease risk. In a 2012 paper, Colditz argues that half of all cancer cases can be prevented, thereby saving more than 280,000 people in 2011, and that individuals, medical and health experts, government officials and others must start taking already known steps to reduce cancer’s impact.{{cite news | last = Harmon | first = Katherine | title = U.S. Cancer Rates Could Be Cut in Half Today Based on What’s Already Known | newspaper = Scientific American | date = March 2012 | url = http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/2012/03/28/u-s-cancer-rates-could-be-cut-in-half-today-based-on-whats-already-known/ | accessdate = 6 April 2012}} '''2011 — Blood-related cancers''' * Siteman completes its 5,000th [[hematopoietic stem cell transplantation]], a common therapy for patients with blood-related cancers such as [[leukemia]], [[lymphoma]], and [[multiple myeloma]] or another blood-related cancer.{{cite news | last = Gamble | first = Molly | title = 70 Hospitals and Health Systems With Great Oncology Programs | newspaper = Becker’s Hospital Review | date = 18 January 2012 | url = http://www.beckershospitalreview.com/lists/hospitals-and-health-systems-with-great-oncology-programs/all-pages.html | accessdate = 20 June 2012}} '''2010 — Pediatric cancers''' * Washington University School of Medicine and [[St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital]] announce their joint Pediatric Cancer Genome Project to identify the genetic changes that give rise to some of the world’s deadliest childhood cancers. The team plans to decode the genomes of more than 600 childhood cancer patients who have contributed tumor samples.{{cite news | last = Szabo | first = Liz | title = Genetic study targets cancer in kids | newspaper = USA Today | date = 26 January 2010 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/printedition/life/20100126/genome26_st.art.htm | accessdate = 20 June 2012}} '''2008 — Genetic sequencing''' * For the first time, scientists decode all the genes of a cancer patient and find a suite of mutations that might have caused the disease or aided its progression. [[Timothy Ley]], M.D., [[Elaine Mardis]], Ph.D., [[Richard K. Wilson]], Ph.D., and their colleagues at [[McDonnell Genome Institute]] say the finding could lead to new therapies and could help doctors make better choices among existing treatments, based on a more detailed genetic picture of each patient's cancer. Though the research involved [[acute myelogenous leukemia]] (AML), the same techniques can also be used to study other cancers.{{cite news | last = Grady | first = Denise | title = Experts Decode Cancer Patient’s Genes, Seeking Treatment Clues | newspaper = They New York Times | date = 6 November 2008 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/06/health/research/06cancer.html | accessdate = 20 July 2012}} '''2007 — Nanotechnology and radiation therapy''' * Gregory Lanza, M.D., Ph.D., Samuel Wickline, M.D., and researchers in their labs announce the development of [[nanoparticles]], significantly smaller than the width of a human hair, aimed at attacking cancer by locating and “latching on” to tumors. Used in conjunction with [[magnetic resonance imaging]], the nanoparticles could help physicians monitor cancerous tissue and deliver medicine directly to the tumor, not to the rest of the body.{{cite news | title = Nanoparticles used to track cells | newspaper = UPI | date = 27 July 2007 | url = http://www.upi.com/Science_News/2007/03/27/Nanoparticles-used-to-track-cells/UPI-90741175008534/ | accessdate = 25 July 2012}} * Researchers led by Daniel Low, Ph.D., and Parag Parikh, M.D., develop a machine called the 4D Phantom that follows a patient’s complex breathing pattern to deliver radiation therapy to tumors that move, such as those in the lung.{{cite news | last = Melcer | first = Rachel | title = Innovating with Daniel Low | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | location = St. Louis | pages = B4 | date = 27 July 2007 }} '''2006 — Photoacoustic imaging''' * Lihong Wang, Ph.D., announces his work on [[photoacoustic imaging]], a new technique that uses light and sound to create detailed, color pictures of tumors and organs. The noninvasive imaging technique, which can be performed without the dangers of radiation exposure associated with [[X-ray]] and [[CT scans]], also may help doctors detect cancer earlier than ever before, its developers say.{{cite video | people = Lihong Wang, Ph.D. | title = New technique brings cancer screening into sharper focus | medium = Web news | publisher = Reuters | location = St. Louis | date = 30 April 2012 | url = https://www.reuters.com/video/2012/04/30/new-technique-brings-cancer-screening-in?videoId=234198822 | accessdate = 25 June 2012}}ß '''2003 — Breast cancer''' * Thalachallour Mohanakumar, Ph.D., and other researchers at Siteman develop and test on mice a prototype vaccine that causes cancerous tumors to stop growing, then to shrink. The vaccine, which is being developed to fight breast cancer in humans, helps the immune system target a protein found in 80 percent of breast tumors.{{cite news | title = Breast cancer vaccine ready for tests soon | newspaper = The Daily Telegraph | date = 10 March 2005 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/3315963/Breast-cancer-vaccine-ready-for-tests-soon.html | accessdate = 15 June 2012}} '''2001 — Imaging and the immune system’s role in controlling cancer''' * Research led by Joanne Mortimer, M.D., shows that [[positron emission tomography]] (PET) scans can often identify within two weeks which women with advanced breast cancer are likely to respond to [[hormone therapy]], a gentler alternative to chemotherapy that is usually just as effective.{{cite news | last = Hesman | first = Tina | title = Scan test may aid choice for breast cancer therapy | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | location = St. Louis | pages = C5 | date = 15 June 2001 }} * [[Robert D. Schreiber]], Ph.D., and colleagues publish the first evidence that the immune system plays a role in controlling cancer, a process called immunosurveillance.{{cite news | last = Siegel | first = Judy | title = Immune system shown to prevent and shape cancer susceptibility | newspaper = The Jerusalem Post | location = Jerusalem | pages = 4 | date = 29 April 2001 }} In 2007, they find in mice that some cancers are kept in a state of “equilibrium,” which leads them to suggest that one day [[immunotherapy]] may convert cancer into a chronic but controllable disease.{{cite news | last = Derbyshire | first = David | title = Living your entire life with cancer – Keeping disease dormant | newspaper = The Daily Telegraph | location = Surry Hills, Australia | pages = 25 | date = 21 November 2007 }} * Molecular oncologist Howard McLeod announces research on a genetic mutation that affects how well patients will respond to chemotherapy. The findings may make possible a blood test that would determine what dose, or even which drugs, would be most effective for each patient.{{cite news | title = Cancer Care Tied to Genetic Makeup | newspaper = The Toronto Star | pages = A06 | date = 26 March 2001 }} '''1998 — Biopsies''' * Ralph G. Dacey Jr., M.D., performs the world's first magnetic [[stereotactic surgery]] to biopsy a human brain tumor using an indirect route to the tumor. The route is designed to avoid regions that would normally be entered when a surgeon manually inserts a surgical tool straight at a site. The investigational computerized system allows surgeons to carefully manipulate surgical tools inside the brain through the use of a catheter driven by precisely controlled magnetic fields.{{cite news | title = First magnet-controlled brain surgery performed | newspaper = BBC News | date = 23 December 1998 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/241244.stm | accessdate = 13 April 2012}} '''1994 — Genetic screening test for thyroid cancer''' * Led in part by Helen Donis-Keller, Ph.D., researchers for the first time develop genetic screening tests that detect a rare, lethal form of [[thyroid cancer]] in the preclinical state, permitting early treatment in children predisposed to the disease. It was the first surgical prevention of cancer based on genetic test results.{{cite news | last = Signor | first = Roger | title = WU Surgeons Remove Gland, Cancer Threat | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | location = St. Louis, Missouri | pages = 1A | date = 29 June 1994 }} '''1979 — Bone marrow transplants''' * As part of a clinical trial, [[leukemia]] patients at Washington University in St. Louis and four other medical centers receive transplants of their healthy bone marrow cells to determine how effective the procedure is in conjunction with chemotherapy and radiation treatment. The new technique would later be called autologous [[hematopoietic stem cell transplantation]].{{cite news | title = Leukemia Victims Get Own Marrow In Transplants | newspaper = The Washington Post | location = Washington, D.C. | pages = A9 | date = 24 August 1979 }} '''Mid-1970s — Imaging''' * [[Michel Ter-Pogossian]], Ph.D., leads the research that will turn the PET scanner from an intriguing concept to a medical imaging technique used by hospitals and laboratories everywhere to scan the working brain.{{cite news | last = Saxon | first = Wolfgang | title = Michel M. Ter-Pogossian, 71; Led Research on PET Scanner | newspaper = The New York Times | date = 21 June 1996 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/us/michel-m-ter-pogossian-71-led-research-on-pet-scanner.html | accessdate = 4 April 2012}}{{cite journal | last = Ter-Pogossian | first = M.M. | last2 = Phelps | first2 = M.E. | last3 = Hoffman | first3 = E.J. | last4 = Mullani | first4 = N.A. | title = A positron-emission transaxial tomograph for nuclear imaging (PETT) | journal = Radiology | volume = 114| issue = 1 | pages = 89–98 | publisher = Radiological Society of North America | location = Philadelphia, Pa. | date = January 1975 | url = http://radiology.rsna.org/content/114/1/89.abstract?sid=eebd7dd6-23bb-4b96-b2ea-fd17b577005a | issn = 0033-8419 | doi = 10.1148/114.1.89 | accessdate = 13 April 2012 | pmid=1208874}} '''1954 — Growth factors and cancer''' * [[Rita Levi-Montalcini]], Ph.D., and [[Stanley Cohen (biochemist)|Stanley Cohen]], Ph.D., isolate for the first time [[nerve growth factor]], a potent substance that promotes nerve cell growth. The discovery later leads to insights into cancer and birth defects, and in 1986 the two are awarded a [[Nobel Prize]] for their work.{{cite news | title = The New Nobels | newspaper = Newsweek | pages = 111 | date = 27 October 1986 }} '''1946 — Radiocarbon in cancer research''' * For the first time, the [[United States Department of War]] releases [[carbon-14]] isotopes to a civilian entity, Siteman’s predecessor institutions, Barnard Free Skin and Cancer Hospital (founded in 1905) and the Mallinckrodt Institute of Radiology (founded in 1923), where they are used in cancer studies.{{cite journal | last = Tilyou | first = Sarah M. | title = History of Nuclear Medicine in St. Louis: A City of Nuclear Medicine Landmarks and Innovators | journal = The Journal of Nuclear Medicine | volume = 30 | issue = 5 | pages = 569–579 | publisher = Society of Nuclear Medicine | location = Reston, Va. | date = May 1989 | url = http://jnm.snmjournals.org/search?submit=yes&pubdate_year=1989&volume=30&firstpage=569&doi=&author1=&author2=&title=&andorexacttitle=and&titleabstract=&andorexacttitleabs=and&fulltext=&andorexactfulltext=and&fmonth=&fyear=&tmonth=&tyear=&journalcode=jnumed&flag=&format=standard&hits=10&sortspec=relevance&submit=yes&submit=Submit | issn = 0161-5505 | accessdate = 13 April 2012}} '''1941 — Cyclotron''' * At the Mallinckrodt Institute of Radiology, construction begins on the first [[cyclotron]] devoted to medical and biological research.{{cite journal | last = Tilyou | first = Sarah M. | title = History of Nuclear Medicine in St. Louis: A City of Nuclear Medicine Landmarks and Innovators | journal = The Journal of Nuclear Medicine | volume = 30 | issue = 5 | pages = 569–579 | publisher = Society of Nuclear Medicine | location = Reston, Va. | date = May 1989 | url = http://jnm.snmjournals.org/search?submit=yes&pubdate_year=1989&volume=30&firstpage=569&doi=&author1=&author2=&title=&andorexacttitle=and&titleabstract=&andorexacttitleabs=and&fulltext=&andorexactfulltext=and&fmonth=&fyear=&tmonth=&tyear=&journalcode=jnumed&flag=&format=standard&hits=10&sortspec=relevance&submit=yes&submit=Submit | issn = 0161-5505 | accessdate = 13 April 2012}} '''1933 — Lung cancer surgery and the disease’s link to smoking''' * [[Evarts Ambrose Graham]], M.D., becomes the first surgeon to cure a human case of lung cancer by removing an entire lung during a procedure known as [[pneumonectomy]].{{cite news | title = Medicine: Death of a Surgeon | newspaper = Time | date = 18 March 1957 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,809201-2,00.html | accessdate = 6 April 2012}} In 1950, he and [[Ernst Wynder]], M.D., publish the results of the first large-scale research on smoking, linking prolonged cigarette use to lung cancer.{{Citation | last = White | first = Larry C. | title = Merchants of Death: The American Tobacco Industry | publisher = Beech Tree Books | origyear = 1988 |date=June 1988 | edition = 1 | isbn = 0688067069}} ==Cancer prevention and control== Siteman and Washington University School of Medicine are actively engaged in many projects to prevent cancer in the St. Louis region and across the United States. These efforts include: * The [[Your Disease Risk]] website, an interactive tool that helps people estimate their risk of cancer, diabetes, heart disease, osteoporosis and stroke, and suggests preventative measures that help lower the likelihood of developing each disease.{{cite news | title = Health Scan: Scientists learn how colon cancer spreads | newspaper = The Jerusalem Post | date = 23 September 2007 | url = http://www.jpost.com/HealthAndSci-Tech/Health/Article.aspx?id=76039 | accessdate = 15 June 2012}} * Zuum, a free [[mobile app]] for [[iPad]] that estimates a person’s risk of cancer, heart disease, diabetes and other diseases, and offers customized tips for prevention and boosting one’s overall health.{{cite web | title = Zuum – Health Tracker | url= https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/zuum-health-tracker/id521273376?mt=8 | accessdate = 26 June 2012}} * "Together - Every Woman's Guide to Preventing Breast Cancer," a free e-book for iPads that provides practical, science-based advice for lowering breast cancer risk at nearly every stage of life.{{cite web | title = TOGETHER - Every Woman's Guide to Preventing Breast Cancer | url= https://itunes.apple.com/us/book/together-every-womans-guide/id1020301603?mt=11 | accessdate = 14 September 2015}} * Research examining cancer disparities, cancer communications and tobacco use.{{Cite news | last = Wittenauer | first = Cheryl | title = Mo. Blacks closing racial gap in new cancer cases | pages = | newspaper = The Associated Press | location = St. Louis |date = 24 September 2008 | url = http://www.semissourian.com/story/1464327.html | accessdate = 26 June 2012}}{{cite news | last = Jackson Jr. | first = Harry | title = Black St. Louisans get healthy at church | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 23 August 2004 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=%22Black%20St.%20Louisans%20get%20healthy%20at%20church%22 | accessdate = 24 June 2013}}{{subscription needed}}{{Cite news | last = Sheridan | first = Kerry | title = Half of all cancers are preventable: study | newspaper = Agence France Presse | location = Washington, D.C. | date = 28 March 2012 | url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iuoQoozpIQ53OFgTHAGLP0EpsN9Q?docId=CNG.26c55fbe5d76c994d00951f5556fe438.2e1 | accessdate = 26 June 2012}} ==Education and community outreach== In addition to treatment and research programs, Siteman is involved with community outreach, education and screening. Efforts include: * The Program for the Elimination of Cancer Disparities (PECaD), which develops cancer prevention and awareness messages, reports research findings to the community, hosts continuing medical education events and engages in other activities.{{cite news | last = Gregorian | first = Cynthia Billhartz | title = Researchers target cancer screenings among blacks | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 27 October 2010 | url = http://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/health-med-fit/fitness/article_add43c5c-bece-5d13-b935-ca4e3642dada.html | accessdate = 20 July 2012}} * Placing information about breast cancer and mammograms in Laundromats, where a study has shown it’s more likely to be seen than in other community settings by women who lack access to adequate health care.{{cite news | last = Jackson Jr. | first = Harry | title = Black St. Louisans get healthy at church | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 23 August 2004 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=%22Black%20St.%20Louisans%20get%20healthy%20at%20church%22 | accessdate = 24 June 2013}}{{subscription needed}}{{cite journal | last = Kreuter | first = Matthew W. | last2 = Alcaraz | first2 = Kassandra I. | last3 = Pfeiffer | first3 = Debra | last4 = Christopher | first4 = Kara | title = Using Dissemination Research to Identify Optimal Community Settings for Tailored Breast Cancer Information Kiosks | journal = Journal of Public Health Management and Practice | volume = 14 | issue = 2 | pages = 160–169 | publisher = Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, Inc. | date = March–April 2008 | url = http://journals.lww.com/jphmp/Abstract/2008/03000/Using_Dissemination_Research_to_Identify_Optimal.14.aspx | doi = 10.1097/01.PHH.0000311895.57831.02 | accessdate = 9 April 2012 | pmid = 18287923}} * A mobile mammography van that offers screenings by appointment in St. Louis and surrounding communities.{{cite news | title = Charity Race Raised More Than $500,000 to Fight Breast Cancer | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | date = 28 October 2000 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=CHARITY%20RACE%20RAISED%20MORE%20THAN%20$%20500,000%20TO%20FIGHT%20BREAST%20CANCER | accessdate = 24 June 2013}}{{cite web | title = Mammography Van | publisher= Siteman Cancer Center | url= http://www.siteman.wustl.edu/contentpage.aspx?id=188 | accessdate = 6 April 2012}} ==Siteman Cancer Network== In 2017, Siteman Cancer Center launched the Siteman Cancer Network, an affiliation with regional medical centers that is aimed at improving the health of individuals and communities through cancer research, treatment and prevention. Network members are [[Page name#BJC HealthCare|Boone Hospital Center]]'s Stewart Cancer Center in [[Columbia, Missouri]]{{cite news |last=Jackson Jr. |first=Jodie |date=4 March 2017 |title=Stewart Cancer Center joins new Siteman network |url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/65654686-05b9-50e7-9129-58b2de5be8e4.html |work=Columbia Daily Tribune |accessdate=14 August 2018}} and Phelps County Regional Medical Center's Delbert Day Cancer Institute in [[Rolla, Missouri]].{{cite news |last=Amos |first=Lori |date=26 June 2018 |title=PCRMC advancing treatment in the community |url=http://www.therolladailynews.com/news/20180626/pcrmc-advancing-treatment-in-community |work=Rolla Daily News |accessdate=14 August 2018}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.siteman.wustl.edu/ Alvin J. Siteman Cancer Center] * [http://medschool.wustl.edu/ Washington University School of Medicine] * [http://www.barnesjewish.org/ Barnes-Jewish Hospital] * [http://www.yourdiseaserisk.wustl.edu/ Your Disease Risk] [[Category:Cancer hospitals]] [[Category:NCI-designated cancer centers]] [[Category:Academic health science centres]] [[Category:Medical research institutes in the United States]] [[Category:Cancer organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Teaching hospitals in Missouri]] [[Category:Hospitals in St. Louis]] [[Category:Central West End, St. Louis]] [[Category:Hospitals established in 1999]]

{{Advert|date=March 2011}} [[File:asahia.JPG|thumb|right|300px|People performing Asahi in a park.]] '''''Asahi''''' (or ''Asahi Health'') is a Finnish health exercise based on the eastern traditions of [[T'ai chi ch'uan]], [[qigong]], [[yiquan]] and [[yoga]], with a western scientific viewpoint. Asahi is designed to suit everybody, regardless of physical condition or age. Asahi exercise is taught and performed in instructed groups, but Asahi can also be performed alone as a form of daily self-treatment. Asahi exercise is ideal for short breaks. ==The History of Asahi== Asahi was created in [[Finland]] 2004 by professional sports instructors and martial artists Timo Klemola, Ilpo Jalamo, Keijo Mikkonen and Yrjö Mähönen. They all had high regards towards classical body development techniques such as [[karate]], [[T'ai chi ch'uan]], [[yiquan]] and [[yoga]], but these styles, as rewarding as they are, seemed to attract only a small marginal of the Finnish population. These classical styles are quite complex and therefore may have a high starting level. They use concepts such as [[qi]] and [[prana]], which may seem mystical to western people. The purpose of Asahi was to get the best out of these techniques, put it in the most simplified form, make it overall scientific and turn it into an easily approachable form - a health exercise for everybody with no starting level at all.[http://www.6d.fi/folder.2006-09-27.0655303114/page.2006-10-25.5371365665/view?searchterm=asahi SixDegrees article Asahi - Designed for Health]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} 2006-09-27 Asahi is designed to treat and prevent shoulder- and back problems, fractures due to falling down and stress-related psychosomatic problems. ==The Principles of Asahi== Asahi is a series of slow movements, completed in silence. It looks harmonious and beautiful, a bit like [[qigong]]. The basic six principles of Asahi are: 1. The linking of movement and breath
2. Practicing vertically erect body alignment
3. Whole body movement
4. Listening to the slow motion
5. Cultivating the mind with mental images
6. The exercise as a continual, flowing experience
The Asahi movements are soft and performed in the rhythm of breathing. The series is simple and easy to learn. The movements have also a practical function, for example picking up a ball from the floor or improving one’s balance by standing on one foot. Advanced levels are designed for long-term trainees, yet they are equally simple to learn. ==Distribution== Asahi can be practiced in major areas of Finland. Asahi Health Ltd has also been accepted as an Education Partner to [[Federation of International Sports, Aerobics and Fitness]] as the first Body Mind -product to be recognized and recommended by this organization.{{Cite web |url=http://www.asahi.fi/index.php?id=26 |title=Asahi Health homepages - Asahi International |access-date=2008-07-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004124026/http://www.asahi.fi/index.php?id=26 |archive-date=2011-10-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==See also== *[[qigong]] *[[yiquan]] *[[T'ai chi ch'uan]] *[[yoga]] *[[Federation of International Sports, Aerobics and Fitness]] ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * Ilpo Jalamo, Timo Klemola, Keijo Mikkonen, Yrjö Mähönen: "Asahi - terveysliikuntaa kaikille." Edita Publishing Oy, 2007. {{ISBN|978-951-37-5003-9}}, {{ISBN|951-37-5003-5}} ==External links== *[http://www.asahi.fi Asahi Health Homepage] [[Category:Meditation]] [[Category:Mind–body interventions]] [[Category:Physical exercise]]

'''Aversion to happiness''', also called '''cherophobia''' or '''fear of happiness''', is an attitude towards [[happiness]] in which individuals may deliberately avoid experiences that invoke positive emotions or happiness.<ref>{{cite journal|last2= Lepshokova|first2= Z. K.|last3= Panyusheva|first3= T.|last4= Natalia|first4= A.|last5= Poon|first5= W.-C.|last6= Yeung|first6= V. W.-l.|last7= Sundaram|first7= S.|last8= Achoui|first8= M.|last9= Asano|first9= R.|date= 3 October 2013|title= Cross-Cultural Validation of Fear of Happiness Scale Across 14 National Groups|journal= Journal of Cross-Cultural Psychology|volume= 45|issue= 2|pages= 246–264|doi= 10.1177/0022022113505357|last1= Joshanloo|first1= M.|last10= Igarashi|first10= T.|last11=Tsukamoto|first11= S.|last12= Rizwan|first12= M.|last13= Khilji|first13= I. A.|last14= Ferreira|first14= M. C.|last15= Pang|first15= J. S.|last16= Ho|first16= L. S.|last17= Han|first17= G.|last18= Bae|first18= J.|last19= Jiang|first19= D.-Y.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Joshanloo|first1= Mohsen|last2= Weijers|first2= Dan|title= Aversion to Happiness Across Cultures: A Review of Where and Why People are Averse to Happiness|journal= Journal of Happiness Studies|date= 15 December 2013|volume= 15|issue= 3|pages= 717–735|doi= 10.1007/s10902-013-9489-9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=B4wtDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA342&dq=cherophobia&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjY9IiuzbrSAhUp94MKHew2BfEQ6AEIMzAE#v=onepage&q=cherophobia&f=false|title= Mosby's Medical Dictionary|last= Mosby|date= 2016-04-29|publisher= Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn= 9780323414265|language= en}}</ref>
One of several reasons why cherophobia may develop is the belief that when one becomes [[Happiness|happy]], a negative event will soon occur that will taint that happiness, as if punishing that individual for satisfaction. This belief is thought to be more prevalent in [[eastern_world|Eastern]] cultures. In [[Western cultures]], such as [[American culture]], "it is almost taken for granted that happiness is one of the most important values guiding people's [[personal life | lives]]". Western cultures are more driven by an urge to maximize happiness and to minimize sadness. Failing to appear happy often gives cause for concern. The value placed on happiness echoes through Western [[positive psychology]] and through research on subjective well-being.<ref>{{citation |url= https://www.springer.com/about+springer/media/springer+select?SGWID=0-11001-6-1457741-0 |title= What's so bad about feeling happy? |date= 17 March 2014 |author= Joan Robinson |publisher= Springer}}</ref>. Fear of happiness is associated with fragility of happiness beliefs, suggesting that one of the causes of aversion to happiness may be the belief that happiness is unstable and fragile.<ref>{{cite journal|url= https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10902-014-9553-0|title= Fragility of Happiness Beliefs Across 15 National Groups|first1= Mohsen|last1= Joshanloo|first2= Dan|last2= Weijers|first3= Ding-Yu|last3= Jiang|first4= Gyuseog|last4= Han|first5= Jaechang|last5= Bae|first6= Joyce S.|last6= Pang|first7= Lok Sang|last7= Ho|first8= Maria Cristina|last8= Ferreira|first9= Melikşah|last9= Demir|first10= Muhammad|last10= Rizwan|first11= Imran Ahmed|last11= Khilji|first12= Mustapha|last12= Achoui|first13= Ryosuke|last13= Asano|first14= Tasuku|last14= Igarashi|first15= Saori|last15= Tsukamoto|first16= Sanne M. A.|last16= Lamers|first17= Yücel|last17= Turan|first18= Suresh|last18= Sundaram|first19= Victoria Wai Lan|last19= Yeung|first20= Wai-Ching|last20= Poon|first21= Zarina Kh|last21= Lepshokova|first22= Tatiana|last22= Panyusheva|first23= Amerkhanova|last23= Natalia|date= 1 October 2015|publisher= |journal= Journal of Happiness Studies|volume= 16|issue= 5|pages= 1185–1210|accessdate= 9 February 2018|via= link.springer.com|doi= 10.1007/s10902-014-9553-0}}</ref> Research shows that fear of happiness is associated with avoidant and anxious [[attachment styles]].<ref> {{cite journal |url= https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2017.11.016 |title= Fear and fragility of happiness as mediators of the relationship between insecure attachment and subjective well-being |first= Mohsen|last= Joshanloo |publisher= |journal= Personality and Individual Differences |volume= 123|pages= 115–118 |accessdate= 9 February 2018 |doi= 10.1016/j.paid.2017.11.016 }} </ref>
==Cultural factors== There are four major reasons why cherophobes avoid happiness: "believing that being happy will provoke bad things to happen; that happiness will make you a worse person; that expressing happiness is bad for you and others; and that pursuing happiness is bad for you and others".<ref>{{citation |title=It's time for Western psychology to recognise that many individuals, and even entire cultures, fear happiness |url=http://digest.bps.org.uk/2014/07/its-time-for-western-psychology-to.html |publisher=[[The British Psychological Society]] |date=21 July 2014 |accessdate=October 4, 2014}}.</ref> For example, "some people—in Western and Eastern cultures—are wary of happiness because they believe that bad things, such as unhappiness, suffering, and death, tend to happen to happy people."<ref name="livescience44233">{{citation |title=Why Happiness Scares Us |author=Stephanie Pappas |url=http://www.livescience.com/44233-fear-of-happiness.html |publisher=[[LiveScience]] |date=20 March 2014 |accessdate=4 October 2014}}.</ref>
These findings "call into question the notion that happiness is the ultimate goal, a belief echoed in any number of articles and [[self-help]] publications about whether certain choices are likely to make you happy".<ref name="livescience44233"/> Also, "in cultures that believe worldly happiness to be associated with sin, shallowness, and moral decline will actually feel less satisfied when their lives are (by other standards) going well",<ref>{{citation |title=13 of Psychology’s Newest and Coolest Ideas |author=Susan Krauss Whitbourne |url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/fulfillment-any-age/201304/13-psychology-s-newest-and-coolest-ideas |publisher=[[Psychology Today]] |date=6 April 2013 |accessdate=4 October 2014}}.</ref> so measures of personal happiness cannot simply be considered a yardstick for satisfaction with one's life, and attitudes such as aversion to happiness have important implications for measuring happiness across cultures and ranking nations on [[Happiness economics|happiness scores]].
==References== {{wiktionary|cherophobia}} {{reflist}}

{{PHL}} |date={{start date|2015|7|15}} |cause=Tainted candy |casualties1=1,925 (As of July 13, 2015){{cite news|title=Number of people sick from Davao candies jumps to 2,000|url=http://www.rappler.com/news/99214-fda-investigation-durian-candies-poisoning|accessdate=14 July 2015|publisher=Rappler|date=13 July 2015}} |reported deaths=21 |arrests=9 |suspects= |accused= |charges= |verdict= }} Almost 2,000 people, mostly schoolchildren from the [[Caraga Region]], experienced [[food poisoning]] after consuming [[durian]], [[mangosteen]], and [[mango]] flavored candies. ==Victims== Most of the victims of the food poisoning incident were schoolchildren within the [[Caraga Region]]. Victims reported of experiencing symptoms such as [[diarrhea]], [[dizziness]], and [[stomachache]]. The cases were reported by at least nine health facilities based in [[Surigao del Sur]], [[Surigao del Norte]] and [[Agusan del Sur]].{{cite news|last1=Cultura|first1=Rodge|title=Candies down over 1,600; poisoning outbreak declared|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/07/11/15/food-poison-outbreak-declared-caraga-region|accessdate=14 July 2015|agency=ABS-CBN News Caraga and Agence France-Presse|publisher=ABS-CBN News|date=11 July 2015}} The first cases were reported in [[Cagwait, Surigao del Sur]] in the morning of July 10.{{cite news|last1=Mascariñas|first1=Erwin|title=Food poisoning cases in Caraga region reach 1,699; candy-maker denies responsibility|url=http://www.mindanews.com/top-stories/2015/07/11/food-poisoning-cases-in-caraga-region-reach-1699-candy-maker-denies-responsibility/|accessdate=14 July 2015|publisher=Minda News|date=11 July 2015|location=Cagayan de Oro}} Poisonings were reported in the following towns: {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;[[Surigao del Sur]] *[[Carrascal, Surigao del Sur|Carrascal]] *[[Cagwait, Surigao del Sur|Cagwait]] *[[Cortes, Surigao del Sur]] *[[Lianga, Surigao del Sur|Lianga]] *[[San Agustin, Surigao del Sur|San Agustin]] *[[Madrid, Surigao del Sur|Madrid]] *[[Marihatag, Surigao del Sur|Marihatag]] *[[Tago, Surigao del Sur|Tago]] *[[Tandag]] {{col-2}} ;[[Surigao del Norte]] *[[Placer, Surigao del Norte|Placer]] *[[Surigao City]] ;[[Agusan del Sur]] *[[Bayugan]] {{col-end}} ==Response== Acting Mayor Paolo Duterte of [[Davao City]] ordered an urgent investigation on July 10 regarding the matter to determine the exact cause of the candy poisoning incident.{{cite news|last1=Caduaya|first1=Editha|title=Acting Davao mayor orders probe into durian candy poisoning|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/98995-davao-mayor-orders-probe-durian-candy-poisoning|accessdate=14 July 2015|publisher=Rappler|date=11 July 2015}} On July 11, 2015, the [[Department of Health (Philippines)|Department of Health]] in the Caraga declared a food poisoning outbreak in the region. Hospitals across the Caraga Region were put into white alert in response to the poisoning incident. ==Investigation== ===Tainted candy=== The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has traced the tainted candies' origin to two manufacturing facilities in [[Davao City]]. The FDA has linked two candy manufacturers to the poisoning incident based on labels found on the food products, one which is licensed with the food safety authority and the other manufacturer, Wendy's Durian Candies is not in the database of the FDA. Janet Aquino of Wendy's Durian Candies said the candies were apparently repacked when she saw the candies made by her company in news report. She noted that the candies' packages included a cut-up portions of the original label of the products. The FDA has also conducted a Microbiological tests on the samples of the tainted candies and is suspecting that the candies were contaminated by [[E. Coli]], [[Salmonella]] or staphylococcus based on the reported symptoms by victims of the food poisoning incident.{{cite news|last1=Dioquino|first1=Rose-An Jessica|title=Salmonella eyed in durian candy poisoning in Surigao del Sur|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/521278/news/regions/salmonella-eyed-in-durian-candy-poisoning-in-surigao-del-sur|accessdate=14 July 2015|publisher=GMA News|date=13 January 2015}} In a press conference on June 16, 2015, announced that the candy samples were tested positive for ''[[staphylococcus aureus]]''.{{cite news|last1=Alvarez|first1=Kathrina Charmaine|title=‘Poisonous’ durian candies test positive for staphylococcus bacteria|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/523454/news/regions/poisonous-durian-candies-test-positive-for-staphylococcus-bacteria|accessdate=22 July 2015|agency=Agence France-Presse, JDS, GMA News|publisher=GMA News|date=16 July 2015}} ===Linked companies=== One of the linked manufacturers to the poisoning incident was Wendy’s Durian Candies. Janet Aquino, whose family runs the manufacturing firm, admitted that her company made the candies linked to the poisonings. However she added that the repacking of the candies by the distributors might be the cause of the poisonings. The Davao City government has suspended the business permit of Wendy's Durian Candies until the business secure a clearance from the FDA. Wendy Aquino, owner of the business, has apologized for the incident in behalf of the company.{{cite news|last1=Caduaya|first1=Editha|title='Sorry,' says durian candymaker over poisoning incident|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/99071-durian-candy-maker-poisoning-apology|accessdate=14 July 2015|publisher=Rappler|date=11 July 2015}} ===Arrests=== Nine men and women linked to the poisonings were arrested. The arrested were identified as vendors; Junnil Martinez, John Oben, Joel Pasa, Richard Rivera Jr, Martinez Bocaycay, Genelyn Pasa, Junnel Teriote, John Dequilla, Henryto Amogui and three more people whose names were not disclosed. Pasa, 26, and Amoguis 21, from Davao City and Valencia, Bukidnon respectively, were seen selling the tainted durian, mango and mangosteen flavored candies at the Special Education Elementary School in [[Tandag]]. The same vendors were also believed to have sold the candies in Aras-Arasan in [[Cagwait]] and [[Carrascal]]. One of those arrested is named John Dequilla, who had been client of Wendy's Durian Candies for at least two years. Janet Aquino, representing the candy manufacturer, said that Dequilla ordered 300 bags of 100-piece packs of candies in July 7 to be delivered in [[Tandag]] in [[Surigao del Sur]]. Aquino noted that it was the first time Dequilla asked for the candies to be delivered in Tandag. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Food safety scandals]] [[Category:Health disasters in the Philippines]] [[Category:2015 health disasters]] [[Category:2015 disasters in the Philippines]] [[Category:History of Agusan del Sur]] [[Category:History of Surigao del Norte]] [[Category:History of Surigao del Sur]] [[Category:Mass poisoning]] [[Category:Poisoning by drugs, medicaments and biological substances]] [[Category:July 2015 events]]

{{Orphan|date=December 2011}}
The '''Center for Personalized Education for Physicians''' ('''CPEP''') is a [[non-profit organization]], headquartered in [[Denver, Colorado]], and it specializes in [[physician]] competency assessment and educational intervention. The organization was established in 1990 as a collaborative effort of seven [[Colorado]] healthcare organizations: the Colorado Alliance for CME, the Colorado Foundation for Medical Care, the Colorado Hospital Association, the [[Colorado Medical Society]], the Colorado Physician Health Program, the Colorado Society of [[Osteopathic medicine in the United States|Osteopathic Medicine]] and the [[University of Colorado School of Medicine]].
CPEP provides assessment and education for physicians re-entering practice. Its approach is based on the idea that education should be directed by an evaluation of the individual's educational needs and that traditional continuing medical education conferences alone may not be effective in improving practice.<ref name=Competency /> This is consistent with the approach of remediation programs both in the United States and internationally.<ref>{{cite web|title=Physician Characteristics and Distribution in the U.S.|publisher=American Medical Association}}</ref> Physicians take part in CPEP programs for medical ethics education and training, to address performance evaluation issues and concerns, and to help them reinstate their medical licenses.
CPEP collaborates with the University of Colorado Schoolof Medicine and is led by faculty and other physician consultants who are board certified in their respective specialties. CPEP is one of five programs nationwide that have been accepted as members of the [http://cpe.memberlodge.org/ Coalition for Physician Enhancement], the primary U.S. organization representing programs that provide physician assessment and education.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cpe.memberlodge.org/Default.aspx?pageId=1213244 |publisher=Coalition for Physician Enhancement |title=About Coalition for Physician Enhancement (CPE) |deadurl=no |accessdate=17 March 2013}}</ref>
CPEP receives no funding from [[Medical license|medical licensure fees]] or state sources. Instead, the organization is supported by participant fees and donations from the Colorado medical community, including the COPIC Companies.
'''Assessment Testing'''
Doctors are referred to CPEP for competency assessments<ref name="Competency" /> from different organizations, including [[hospital]]s, medical groups and state medical boards. The CPEP approach to physician competency evaluation and assessment has three major components: clinical competence assessment, educational intervention, and post-educational evaluation.
The assessment is individualized based on the physician’s practice and the concerns of the referring organization.<ref name="Cognitive" /> The actual assessment includes structured clinical interviews, simulated patient encounters and written testing. This testing is overseen by a [[board-certified]] physician who acts as an associate medical director (AMD). This AMD then compiles a final report, and the physician receives recommendations for education based on their needs.
'''ProBE'''
The ProBE (Professional/Problem-Based Ethics) Program<ref name="Probe" /> started in 1992 in [[New Jersey]] as collaboration between the New Jersey State Board of Medical Examiners and The Ethics Group, LLC. The program started as a way to provide educational intervention to physicians who were identified by the Board and had received ethical infractions.
By 1996, the ProBE Program had been endorsed by 45 licensing boards and sub-specialty boards throughout the [[United States]]. In 2007, CPEP acquired The Ethics Group, LLC, and began offering the program.
The ProBE Program provides education for healthcare professionals, and it focuses on [[ethics]] violations and unprofessional conduct secondary to boundary violations in the practice of healthcare. These violations can include financial irregularities, [[misrepresentation]], [[sexual misconduct]], disruptive behavior and [[substance abuse]]. The class is offered in Denver, Colorado and [[Newark, New Jersey]] in the United States, and [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]].
'''Other Programs'''
CPEP offers a Clinical Practice Reentry Program<ref name="Reentry1" /> for physicians who wish to reenter the field after a voluntary absence to enhance a physician's practice, and/or restore a physician's clinical capabilities. This program evaluates the physician’s clinical skills, including structured clinical interviews and a one-day comprehensive evaluation.<ref name="Reentry4" /> Physicians are then given a reentry plan, which includes supervised clinical experience to update skills and knowledge and a detailed reporting of progress.<ref name="Reentry3" /> To enter this program, physicians must have left the medical field in good standing, and they must want to reenter in the same [[clinical practice]] for which they were trained.<ref name="Reentry2" />
The Patient Care Documentation Seminar teaches physicians how to identify basic documentation guidelines, understand the legal issues associated with poor documentation and overcome barriers to good documentation. Physicians can receive up to eight [[continuing medical education]] credits and up to two Experience Rating System points for taking the class.
The Personalized Implementation Program is the follow-up class to the Patient Care Documentation Seminar. Physicians submit three sets of charts to CPEP at two, four and six months, and they receive feedback via checklists from a [[Consultant (medicine)|medical consultant]] on their progress at two and four months. Physicians then contact CPEP for a telephone conference with a medical reviewer and receive a final report of their progress after the last chart is submitted.

<ref name="Reentry4">Sweeney, E. [http://business.highbeam.com/436011/article-1G1-261319997/physician-reentry-reeducation-programs-help-integrate ''Physician Reentry: Reeducation Programs Help Integrate Medical Staff Members.]'' Briefings on Credentialing: August 1, 2011.</ref> }}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} The '''Centre of Biological Research''' (Spanish: '''Centro de Investigaciones Biológicas''') is a leading research centre in [[Spain]], specialising in [[molecular genetics]]. It belongs to the [[Spanish National Research Council]] (CSIC).
Created in 1958, the centre leads Spanish and European research in the fields of biology and biomedicine. Set up under the auspices of [[Nobel laureate]] [[Santiago Ramón y Cajal]], its first director was [[Gregorio Marañon]]. Leading scientists associated with the centre include [[Mariano Barbacid]].
Originally located in the centre of [[Madrid]], its new facilities at the [[Complutense University of Madrid]] campus were inaugurated on 26 January 2004 by Her Royal Highness [[Infanta Cristina, Duchess of Palma de Mallorca]].
== Research areas == The centre is divided into five departments corresponding to the scientific areas they specialise in: *[[Cellular biology|Cellular]] and [[developmental biology]] *[[Plant biology]] *[[Protein science]] *[[Cellular physiopathology|Cellular]] and [[molecular physiopathology]] *[[Molecular microbiology]]
With 90 staff scientists and some 500 pre-and postdoctoral research fellows, technical and administrative staff, it has a high output in leading English-and Spanish language scientific reviews.
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081228143706/http://www.cib.csic.es/en/que_es.php Official web site - English version]

[[File:Radiograph of impacted wisdom tooth near nerve.jpg|thumb|Wisdom tooth with close association to the inferior alveolar nerve.]] When extracting lower wisdom teeth, '''Coronectomy''' is a treatment option involving removing the crown of the lower wisdom tooth, whilst keeping the roots in place in healthy patients. This option is given to patients as an alternative to extraction when the wisdom teeth are in close association with the inferior alveolar nerve, and so used to prevent damage to the nerve which may occur during extraction.<ref name=":1" />
== Advantages ==
Prevents potential [[neuropathy]]<ref name="SarwarMahmood-Rao2015">{{cite journal|last1=Sarwar|first1=Humera|last2=Mahmood-Rao|first2=Sameer|title=Coronectomy; good or bad?|journal=Dental Update|volume=42|issue=9|year=2015|pages=824–828|issn=0305-5000|doi=10.12968/denu.2015.42.9.824}}</ref>
The risk of altered sensation is significantly lower than convention surgical removal of [[mandibular]] third [[molars]] with 8% of the cases affected temporarily and 3.6% of the cases got permanently affected. 30% of the roots will migrate post-coronectomy, erupting away for the inferior alveolar canal. This makes extraction of the remaining roots safer.
== Disadvantages ==
There is a 5% chance of failure of coronectomy, the root will become mobilized during transection.<ref>{{cite journal|author=O'Riordan, Brian C.|title=Coronectomy (intentional partial odontectomy of lower third molars)|journal=Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology and Endodontics|date=September 2004|volume=98|issue=3|pages=274, 280|doi=10.1016/j.tripleo.2003.12.040|pmid=15356463}}</ref> In 5% of the cases, [[Dental follicle|follicle]] remnants will form deep [[periodontal]] pockets which will lead to infection.<ref>{{cite journal|author=O'Riordan, Brian C.|title=Coronectomy (intentional partial odontectomy of lower third molars)|journal=Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology and Endodontics|date=September 2004|volume=98|issue=3|pages=274, 280|doi=10.1016/j.tripleo.2003.12.040|pmid=15356463}}</ref>
== Indications ==
Coronectomy should be considered if there are signs that the patient is at a high risk of nerve damage during extraction: * Lower wisdom tooth is shown to be close to the inferior alveolar canal radiographically:<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/224005111_Notes_on_coronectomy|title=Notes on coronectomy|last=Renton|first=Tara|date=2012-04-13|volume=212}}</ref> ** Signs of narrowing or diversion of the canal ** Roots are darkened/ Canal is interrupted ** Interruption of [[lamina dura]] ** Juxta-apical region on the [[radiograph]]<ref name=":1">{{cite journal|author=T. Renton|title=Notes on coronectomy|journal=BDJ|date=13 April 2012|issue=212|pages=323, 326|doi=10.1038/sj.bdj.2012.265}}</ref> * Not medically compromised<ref name=":0" /> * Tooth vital, caries/pathology free and non-mobile<ref name=":0" />
== Contraindications ==
* Non-vital tooth * Tooth is mobile or becomes mobile during procedure * Tooth is horizontal or distoangular impacted * Medically compromised patients for example immunocompromised * Patients who are predisposed to local infection for example if they have undergone radiotherapy in the area they may have poor healing.<ref name=":0" /> * Caries or persistent infection<ref name=":0" />
== Procedure ==
=== Preoperative assessment ===
==== The patient ==== The patient should be aware of the potential risks of the procedure such as: * [[Alveolar osteitis|Dry socket]] * Secondary surgical procedures
==== Radiography ==== A plain film radiograph allows the proximity of the tooth to the [[Inferior alveolar nerve|inferior alveolar canal]] to be assessed. The plain film can be assessed to identify the tooth as high risk If there is; loss of the lamina dura, darkening of the canal and grooving of the root. If the mandibular third molar is deemed to be high risk, a cone beam CT ([[Cone beam computed tomography|CBCT]]) is taken in addition to the plain film. The justification of additional radiography can be justified by the surgeon as it allows them to gain further information regarding the tooth roots and the inferior alveolar canal should the roots be mobilised when transecting.
==== Consent ==== Verbal consent must be attained by the surgeon prior to the procedure of a coronectomy. Additionally consent must be gained if removal of the roots is required due to mobilisation. The patient should be informed of early and late infection meaning the roots may need removing.
=== Operative technique === # Long buccal infiltration and anterior buccal infiltration both with 4% [[articaine]], 1:10000ppm of epinephrine. This can be supplemented with an inferior dental block using 2% lidocaine, 1:80000 epinephrine. # The third molar is exposed by raising a buccal triangular mucoperiosteal fold thickness flap. # A fissure bur is used to create a buccal gutter of bone and to expose the ACJ. # Drill directly into pulp at intersection of buccal groove and ACJ. # This cut is lateralised to create a horizontal groove below the level of the ACJ. # The crown can be fractured off the roots using a small elevator such as coupland number 1 or straight Warwick James. # Care must be taken to not apply too much torque to the tooth so minimising root mobilisation. # Use a rose head bur to remove enamel fragments. # Remaining roots should sit a few millimetres below the alveolar crystal bone level, where the pulp should not be touched. # Then follow up with closing the area and suturing. # Post operative [[Chlorhexidine|chlorohexidine]] mouth wash or gel can be prescribed, however antibiotics should not be prescribed unless there is pericoronal infection.
=== Post operative complications ===
==== Early ==== If the patient presents with dry socket, irrigate with chlorohexidine mouthwash and place resorbable dressing such as Alvogyl. If the patient has recurrent infection, consideration to remove the roots should be noted.
==== Late ==== In a few cases the remaining roots may erupt which can minimise the morbidity of the inferior alveolar nerve, however the roots may be in close contact to the inferior alveolar nerve requiring surgical separation. <ref name=":1" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
